TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: izua ti sa Idjuidjung.
izoa ti sa Idjoidjong.
S.TRANSL: There was a person called Idjuidjung.

S.FORM: manu "ari tja paqinatsapaw," aya a se Łinasalas.
mano "ari tja paqinacapaw," aya a se Ljinasalas.
S.TRANSL: The people of Linasalas said: “Let’s go and hunt their heads.”

S.FORM: patadałan ni sa Idjuidjung.
patadaljan ni sa Idjoidjong.
S.TRANSL: Idjuidjung saw them.

S.FORM: "'ai anga tsa vuluq sa kuang, a matu kałałudjełudjen, a matu ngudjungudjułan.
"'ai anga ca voloq sa koang, a mato kaljaljodjeljodjen, a mato ngodjongodjoljan.
S.TRANSL: “Oh dear! Their spears and guns are like thorn-grass and high tree stumps.

S.FORM: gału anan; ku sikesan anan tua puk, sa ku qałidjeladjelavi."
galjo anan; ko sikesan anan toa pok, sa ko qaljidjeladjelavi."
S.TRANSL: Wait a bit. I’ll cook some tree-beans for them, and leave them undercooked.”

S.FORM: makakesa ti sa Idjuidjung.
makakesa ti sa Idjoidjong.
S.TRANSL: Idjuidjung finished his cooking.

S.FORM: "idu anga, ła qała.
"ido anga, lja qalja.
S.TRANSL: “Come on, enemies;

S.FORM: tjupałingu a mamazangiłan, tjuvangavu kiłupetju a vavuluvulungan."
tjopaljingo a mamazangiljan, tjovangavo kiljopetjo a vavolovolongan."
S.TRANSL: chiefs come to the doorway and old men to the skylight to block off our (or their) retreat!”

S.FORM: paqetjetj ti sa Idjuidjung tua puk, sa kadjameq a qała; matsay a mapułat.
paqetjetj ti sa Idjoidjong toa pok, sa kadjameq a qalja; macay a mapoljat.
S.TRANSL: Then Idjuidjung broke wind with the tree-beans, and blasted the enemy, and they all died.

S.FORM: matsidił anga vałut a ti sa Vungavan, djinameq a pitsungal; vaik a sema umaq.
macidilj anga valjot a ti sa Vongavan, djinameq a picongal; vaik a sema omaq.
S.TRANSL: There was just one survivor, Vungavan, who was hit in the knee. He went off home.

S.FORM: ka pakaqiaw mangtjez i umaq.
ka pakaqiaw mangtjez i omaq.
S.TRANSL: He arrived home shouting for help.

S.FORM: "nakuya tsu.
"nakoya co.
S.TRANSL: (The people said:) “This is bad.

S.FORM: ika tjen a nasa venala.
ika tjen a nasa venala.
S.TRANSL: We can’t win.

S.FORM: tja paputsekeław tia Idjuidjung kati Tjukutjuku; sa 'papuvałutu a su qintsi a zua małe taiday,' tja ayavaw ti sa Idjuidjung."
tja papocekeljaw tia Idjoidjong kati Tjokotjoko; sa 'papovaljoto a so qinci a zoa malje taiday,' tja ayavaw ti sa Idjoidjong."
S.TRANSL: Let’s arrange a marriage between Idjuidjung and Tjukutjuku. And let’s say to Idjuidjung: ‘Bring back to life the hundred people you killed’.”

S.FORM: sa vaik a masan kai ti sa Vungavan.
sa vaik a masan kai ti sa Vongavan.
S.TRANSL: Vungavan went as their mouthpiece;

S.FORM: mangtjez i tjai sa Idjuidjung.
mangtjez i tjai sa Idjoidjong.
S.TRANSL: and he reached Idjuidjung’s place.

S.FORM: "papuvałutu a su qintsi; saka taiday a ḍiḍi a gung tu su silisi tjai Tjukutjuku."
"papovaljoto a so qinci; saka taiday a dridri a gong to so silisi tjai Tjokotjoko."
S.TRANSL: “Bring back to life the people you killed; and with a bride-price of a hundred pigs and cows you can marry Tjukutjuku.”

S.FORM: sa papuvałuti a qintsi, sa vaik anga a putsekeł, sa pangtjez i Łinasalas.
sa papovaljoti a qinci, sa vaik anga a pocekelj, sa pangtjez i Ljinasalas.
S.TRANSL: So he brought those killed back to life, and went off to get married, and reached Łinasalas.

S.FORM: sa ka selem sa qereng tia Idjuidjung kati Tjukutjuku; manu demadip ti sa Idjuidjung; manu ka djumaken a kutji, "tjuqtjuqan tua łamłam, sa putsemeli izua zua piqay."
sa ka selem sa qereng tia Idjoidjong kati Tjokotjoko; mano demadip ti sa Idjoidjong; mano ka djomaken a kotji, "tjoqtjoqan toa ljamljam, sa pocemeli izoa zoa piqay."
S.TRANSL: After dark Idjuidjung and Tjukutjuku lay down. Idjuidjung fondled her, and came across her vagina, and said: “Pound some ginger and put it on that wound there.”

S.FORM: "inika piqay azua; avan azua kutji a tja siputseketsekeł."
"inika piqay azoa; avan azoa kotji a tja sipocekecekelj."
S.TRANSL: “That’s not a wound; that’s a vagina for consummating our marriage.”

S.FORM: "uaa, inika ken a tjenglay a piqay izua."
"oaa, inika ken a tjenglay a piqay izoa."
S.TRANSL: “Oh! I don’t like there being a wound there.”

S.FORM: sa vaik a tjumaq.
sa vaik a tjomaq.
S.TRANSL: And he went off home,

S.FORM: masuḍam anga sakamaya tua kutji a piqapiqay.
masodram anga sakamaya toa kotji a piqapiqay.
S.TRANSL: disappointed about the vagina ‘wound’.

S.FORM: "patsikelu anga a ku sinilisi a gung katua ḍiḍi."
"pacikelo anga a ko sinilisi a gong katoa dridri."
S.TRANSL: “Give me back the bride-price of cows and pigs.”

S.FORM: sa pavayan, saka sa vaik anga sakamaya.
sa pavayan, saka sa vaik anga sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: They gave them back, and he just went off.

S.FORM: saka izua saka amin.
saka izoa saka amin.
S.TRANSL: And that’s the end.
